Company2Name: QEP Field Svcs, LLC dba Tesoro Logistics - Rockies

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 
Blacks Fork Gas Plant
Green River Processing, LLC (GRP)

GRP and the Blacks Fork Gas Plant submit this RMP update to reflect the addition of a new fractionation train at the facility.  The addition will result in 4 additional storage vessels: One (1) 30,000 gallon pressurized Propane Storage Tank, one (1) 30,000 gallon pressurized Butane storage tank, and two (2) 90,000 gallon pressurized Flammable Mixture storage tanks.
  
Accidental Release Prevention and Response Policies:
GRP and the Blacks Fork Gas Plant have a long standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated in the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel as well as considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of the facility. Additionally, the Blacks Fork Gas Plant encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention as well as ensures that all contractors are aware of the plant's safety procedures and accident prevention policy.

GRP's policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, plant personnel will respond to contain the release as necessary. GRP's Blacks Fork Gas Plant has coordinated with the Lyman Fire Department for emergency response procedures.

Description of the Stationary Source and Regulated Substances:
The Blacks Fork Gas Plant is located approximately 5 miles southwest of the town of Granger, Wyoming, on the border between Uinta and Sweetwater Counties.
The Blacks Fork facility utilizes field gas that enters the facility and is then separated and routed into three (3) natural gas liquid (NGL) extraction units (BF1 Cryo, BF2 Cryo, and the JT Plant). After processing, the NGLs are sent to either on-site storage, a NGL pipeline, or a fractionation unit (consisting of a deethanizer, depropanizer, debutanizer and a d

eisobutanizer ). The fractionation products ( propane, butane, i-butane)  are condensed and sent to individual storage tanks on site.Each of the three NGL extraction units handle, manufacture, use, or store RMP-regulated substances above their respective threshold quantities, and are consider RMP covered processes.  GRP has determined that the radius of impact from a worst-case release from any of the three processes would not exceed 0.6 miles and qualify for Program 1 due to the plant's distance from any public receptors. The Blacks Fork Gas Plant does not use and/or process any regulated toxic substances above threshold quantities.

Five Year Accident History:
Blacks Fork Gas Plant has an excellent record of accident prevention over the past five (5) years. There have been no onsite or offsite accidents, as defined by EPA's General Guidance on Risk Management Programs. Additionally, there have been no OSHA reportable incidents in the last 5 years.

Emergency Response Program Information:
The Blacks Fork Gas Plant maintains a written Emergency Response Plan, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidentally released. The procedures address the aspects of emergency response including first aid, evacuation plans and accounting for all personnel after an evacuation, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public if a release occurs, and the post incident clean up requirements.

In addition, the plant has procedures that address maintenance, inspection and testing of emergency response equipment as well as instructions that address the use of emergency response equipment.

GRP employees and contractors receive training in these procedures as necessary and have completed a safety plot plan with two (2) designated escape rendezvous area

s in case of an onsite emergency.

Emergency Response Plan is updated as needed and all employees are trained accordingly with each update to the ER Plan.
